docs.lead_paragraph: The Pacific trade deal agreed on Monday, which grants biotechnology drug producers less protection than offered by the United States, could put more downward pressures on the costly drugs' pricing in the industry's most lucrative market.

headline.main: Pacific Trade Deal Adds to U.S. Price Quandary for Biotech Drugs

docs.lead_paragraph: San Francisco, que alguna vez fue el centro de la epidemia del SIDA, ahora solo registra unos cuantos cientos de casos nuevos al año.

headline.main: San Francisco gana terreno en la batalla contra el V.I.H. con un enfoque de avanzada

docs.snippet: San Francisco, que alguna vez fue el centro de la epidemia del SIDA, ahora solo registra unos cuantos cientos de casos nuevos al año.

docs.lead_paragraph: The city that was once the epidemic’s ground zero now has only a few hundred new cases a year, the result of a raft of creative programs.

headline.main: San Francisco Is Changing Face of AIDS Treatment

docs.abstract: San Francisco has drastically reduced HIV infection rates through series of innovative programs, turning city that was once ground zero for disease into example for rest of country; city had 302 new infections in 2014, down from 2,332 at epidemic's peak.
docs.snippet: The city that was once the epidemic’s ground zero now has only a few hundred new cases a year, the result of a raft of creative programs.

docs.lead_paragraph: William Campbell of Drew University, Satoshi Omura of Kitasato University and Youyou Tu of the China Academy of Chinese Medical Sciences won the award.

headline.main: Nobel Prize in Medicine Awarded to 3 Scientists for Parasite-Fighting Therapies
headline.print_headline: 3 Share Nobel for Work on Treatment of ‘Devastating’ Parasitic Diseases

docs.abstract: Scientists William C Campbell, Satoshi Omura and Tu Youyou are jointly awarded Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for their work on treatment of parasitic diseases; Drs Campbell and Omura, who share one-half of $960,000 award, collaborated on remedy for onchocerciasis, or river blindness, while Dr Tu, who won other half, drew on Chinese medicine to develop drug to combat malaria.
docs.snippet: William Campbell of Drew University, Satoshi Omura of Kitasato University and Youyou Tu of the China Academy of Chinese Medical Sciences won the award.

byline.contributor: Jane Perlez contributed reporting from Beijing, and Jonathan Soble from Tokyo.

docs.lead_paragraph: William C. Campbell, Satoshi Omura and Youyou Tu received the 2015 prize for “therapies that have revolutionized the treatment of some of the most devastating parasitic diseases,” the committee said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Three scientists from Japan, China and Ireland whose discoveries led to the development of potent new drugs against parasitic diseases including malaria and elephantiasis won the Nobel Prize for Medicine on Monday.

headline.main: Beating Parasites Wins Three Scientists Nobel Prize for Medicine
headline.print_headline: Beating Parasites Wins Three Scientists Nobel Prize for Medicine

docs.snippet: Three scientists from Japan, China and Ireland whose discoveries led to the development of potent new drugs against parasitic diseases including malaria and elephantiasis won the Nobel Prize for Medicine on Monday.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Nobel prize in medicine went Monday to three scientists hailed as "heroes in the truest sense of the word" for saving millions of lives with the creation of the world's leading malaria-fighting drug and another that has nearly wiped out two devastating tropical diseases.

docs.lead_paragraph: Spark Therapeutics said the treatment had allowed people with certain so-called inherited retinal dystrophies to maneuver in dimmer light than they could before.

headline.main: Eye Treatment Closes In on Being First Gene Therapy Approved in U.S.
headline.print_headline: Eye Treatment Closes In on Being First Gene Therapy Approved in U.S.

docs.abstract: Spark Therapeutcs announces success in late-stage test for medication used in treating inherited eye disease of retina that can cause blindness; is seeking to become first gene therapy to win approval from Food and Drug Admin.
docs.snippet: Spark Therapeutics said the treatment had allowed people with certain so-called inherited retinal dystrophies to maneuver in dimmer light than they could before.
